On 26/11/2007, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> There is a potential for more sophisticated appraches, e.g. maybe
> some kind of hashing scheme, but they would need to promise
> sufficiently impressive results to justify their effort.

Yeh, but maybe some kind of half way scheme whereby you eliminate a
large proportion of the the full on geome comparisons by using
hashcodes (or whatever) but don't go to the extreme of determining
100% if a genome has come before. There is also some benefit to
purging the record of past genomes as the population evolves away from
older structures. Perhaps each genome in the history could have a
decaying cache hit count. And perhaps we could draw some ideas from
garbage collection algorithms where objects exist in one of  2 or 3
generations - (1)high turnover, (2)been around for a while and (3)
structures that seem to stick around.

I reckon with a bit of thought a fairly simple scheme could eliminate
90 to 95% of the redundant evaulations. Motivation would of course be
greater if that 10% was shown to increase as time went on or with
larger pops, etc.

Colin.
